metadata.title: Nano-clay and styrene-butadiene-styrene modified bitumen for improvement of rutting performance in asphalt mixtures containing steel slag aggregates

Nano-clay and styrene-butadiene-styrene modified bitumen for improvement of rutting performance in asphalt mixtures containing steel slag aggregates

h i g h l i g h t s
Enhanced viscosity and improved adhesion to aggregate particles could be regarded as other advantages of Nano polymer modified bitumen. Rutting performance was highly influenced by binder modification in HMA mixtures. In comparison with conventional asphalt mixtures, modified samples possessed higher rates of final strain upon stress enhancement at any temperature.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 15 January 2019 Received in revised form 9 July 2019 Accepted 20 July 2019
Keywords: Asphalt mixture Modified bitumen Polymer sbs Nanomaterials Rheological properties Rutting Wheel track
a b s t r a c t
Nanoparticles have exhibited a promising potential in enhancing the bituminous materials’ performance. As a cost-effective material, hot mix asphalt (HMA) has been employed in pavement structure for a long time. Their viscoelasticity however results in various modes of failure under different temperature profiles and loading stress. Rutting of asphalt pavements is considered as the most prominent distress factor under almost all climate conditions. Moreover, steel slag has been employed for improvement of asphalt mixture properties as it exhibits excellent physical features. In this content the aim of the present research is to analyze improving effects of nano clay and styrene-butadiene-styrene (SBS) on the rutting resistance of modified steel slag asphalt mixture (SSAM). Various tests were employed to investigate the asphalt binder properties and the rheological characteristics of modified bitumen among which penetration grade, softening point, ductility and dynamic shear rheometer (DSR) can be mentioned. Marshal Test was applied to examine the optimum bitumen content in conventional and modified asphalt mixture. The rutting resistance against was then evaluated through two tests: repeated load axial (RLA) test and wheel track test. The results indicated respective improvement of toughness and viscosity by an average of 25% and 101% upon addition of nano-polymer which enhanced the bitumen rheological characteristics while reducing the penetration grade. The asphalt rutting resistance and rutting depth exhibited some improvements as well.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Increasing evidences (such as harsh climate conditions, heavy traffic loads, and increasing axial loads through) have indicated the necessity of improvement in the conventional asphalt. As an organic mixture with wide range of applications in road pavement industry, asphalt has imposed itself as an ideal mixture for this purpose owing to its good viscoelastic features [1]. Asphalt concrete has been long employed in road and airport pavements.
Researchers and engineers have continuously attempted to ameliorate the performance of asphalt pavements. Road pavements must exhibit acceptable resistance against fatigue cracking, rutting, creep and slippage [2]. Load-induced stress can be distributed by application of hot mix asphalt which can secure the underneath unprotected layers from the impacts of water. Asphalt mixture has to demonstrate resistance against weather influences, permanent deformation and cracking resulted by loading and environmental factors [3]. As recovery and reconstruction of traffic load-induced pavement defects is expensive, prevention from the mentioned problems seems more economic.
Rutting of asphalt pavements can occur as a consequence of permanent deformation; the most distressing mechanisms in asphalt pavements. This is a serious issue in almost all climate conditions. Service life of the pavement shows a dramatic decline in regions with higher temperatures; moreover, presence of water in the ruts can give rise to hydroplaning hazard. Other factors like overloading, long steep slopes, low-speed trucks, substance properties, and climate conditions can also influence rutting in asphalt pavement [2]. In this content, many researches have been conducted to investigate the impact of additives on asphalt mixtures to enhance their performance under dynamic loads. Fatigue cracking, rutting, and moisture damage are major flexible pavement distresses adversely affecting pavement performance. With increasing loads and number of axles on the roads, particularly those of overweight (OW) and superheavy loads (SHL), highway agencies need to adopt policies for accommodating this increase without jeopardizing pavement performance [4,5]. One candidate measure could be optimizing mix design process by means of modifying asphalt binder [6]. In the past decades, the demand for modified asphalt binder had a strong increasing trend [7]. The vast application of modified asphalt binder has led all Departments of Transportation (DOT) within U.S. to develop test specifications for modified asphalt binders [8]. Nanotechnology has been introduced to asphalt technologists as recent as past couple of decades, and allowed them to benefit from the unique properties of asphalt binder particles in nanoscale. Nanotechnology deals with particles with at least one characteristics dimension in the length scale of 1–100 nm [9]. In this length scale, asphalt binder particles have different physical and chemical properties mainly due to their high surface area and quantum effects [10]. The history of nanotechnology dates back to exploration of gold colloidal solution by Michael Faraday in 1857 [11]. However, the fundamentals of this science became well established in the past half a century [12]. The application of nanomaterial in pavement engineering is still under investigation. In general, nanomaterials can improve the performance of asphalt mixtures by potentially improving one or some of asphalt mixture properties including adhesion between asphalt binder and aggregates, asphalt binder cohesion, cracking resistance, moisture resistance, wearing course performance, and layer interface bond [13].
In the literature, several nanomaterials have been used as modifier and their effect on mechanical and rheological properties of asphalt binder and mixture has been investigated. Nanoclay, nanosilica, nano-TiO2, nano-ZnO, nano-CaCO3, carbon nanofiber, and Zycosoil are some examples of these nanomaterials. In this study, nano clay was used for modification of asphalt binder. Tests were conducted on rheological and mechanical properties of modified and unmodified (control) asphalt binders to investigate the influence of modification with nano material. Furthermore, effect of nano and polymer on rheological and rutting potential of asphalt mixtures was studied.

sections.heading: 2. Background
sections.text:
Nanoclay has been the topic of several research studies regarding asphalt binder and mixtures modified with nanomaterials. Yao et al. showed that non-polymer-modified and polymer-modified nanoclay positively contribute to fatigue cracking and rutting performance of asphalt mixtures, with polymer-modified nanoclay having a higher positive effect [14]. Jahromi et al. studied rheological properties of asphalt binders modified by nanofil-15 and ccloisite-15A nanoclay and compared the results with those of unmodified (control) asphalt binder [15]. The comparison demonstrated that modified asphalt binders had higher stiffness, lower phase angle, and improved aging resistance. Zare-Shahabadi et al.
showed an improvement on low temperature and cracking rheological properties of asphalt binders modified with bentonite clay (BC) and organically modified bentonite (OBT) [16]. Goh et al. investigated the effect of water and deicing chemicals on nanoclay modified binder and observed a lower moisture damage potential for modified mixtures versus control mixtures for seven freezethaw cycles [17]. Another study showed that nanoclay-modified asphalt binder had a higher shear complex modulus [18].
Nanosilica was used as asphalt binder modifier in a number of studies. Yao et al. concluded nanosilica-modified asphalt binder had slightly lower viscosity, less dissipated energy per load per cycle, and lower oxidation potential, with similar low temperature characteristics [19]. Furthermore, mixtures constructed with nanosilica-modified asphalt binders had a higher dynamic modulus, and improved flow number, as well as improved rutting and fatigue resistance. In another study, the combined effect of polymer modification and nanosilica modification on asphalt mixture stiffness was investigated. It was suggested to use 4% nanosilica (by weight of asphalt binder) to have the greatest improvements in terms of long-term aging and moisture susceptibility [20]. Nano-TiO2, nano-ZnO, and nano-CaCO3 were also used as asphalt binder modifiers in several studies. Hamedi et al. carried out Lottman modified test on Nano-CaCO3-modified asphalt mixtures with different dosages and concluded that tensile strength ratio (TSR) for modified asphalt mixtures increased significantly, revealing the positive effect of Nano-CaCO3 on moisture susceptibility [21]. In another study, aggregates were modified by nano-CaCO3 and nano-ZnO [22]. Mixture constructed with modified aggregates were evaluated for moisture susceptibility. Results showed modified mixtures had a better moisture susceptibility compared to control asphalt mixtures, with a higher positive impact of nanoCaCO3 compared to nano-ZnO. Azarhoosh et al. employed surface free energy method to investigate aggregate-mastic interface bond strength to predict fatigue life of hot-mix asphalt (HMA) containing different nano-TiO2 percentages [23]. The developed model revealed that nano-TiO2 modified mixtures had a better fatigue life compared to control mixtures, and theoretical results were verified with laboratory experiments. Shafabaskh et al. performed in-direct tensile fatigue (ITF) and repeated load axial (RLA) tests on nanoTiO2-modified and control mixtures, and showed a better fatigue cracking and rutting performance of the modified mixtures [24]. Carbon nanofibers (CNFs) were used as asphalt binder modifier by Khattak et al. [25]. They used CNF in wet and dry processes to fabricate asphalt mixture. Authors concluded that CNF modification led to better rutting resistance and significant fatigue life improvement. Zycosoil is another nanomaterial, which was used by Moghadas Nejad et al. to evaluate its effect on moisture susceptibility of HMA with limestone and granite aggregates in indirect tensile strength and fatigue tests [26]. It was concluded that moisture damage susceptibility decreased with using Zycosoil, with a higher impact on mixtures with granite aggregates. Authors concluded that Zycosoil decreased surface free energy of aggregates, thus the potential of moisture damage due to formation of aggregate-water bond decreased. The above-mentioned nanomaterials had generally positive influence on fatigue cracking, rutting, and moisture damage of asphalt mixtures.
The purpose of this work is to examine the rheological and mechanical properties of hot mix asphalt (HMA) and Nanopolymer modified binders. For this aim, various percentages of Nano and polymer composite materials were employed. Bitumen tests then evaluated the rheological characteristics of modified bitumen samples. Furthermore, Marshal Test was applied to determine the optimum content of bitumen of conventional and modified asphalt mixture. The rutting and creep resistance were also assessed through use of repeated load axial (RLA) and wheel track tests.

sections.heading: 3.1. Materials
sections.text:
The aggregates applied in the present study included Natural Aggregate1 + 50% steel slag in form of fine and coarse aggregates graded by the continuous type IV scale of the AASHTO standard as provided in Table 1. Nano and polymer composites were mixed with a 60/70 penetration grade WMA asphalt binder (AC-10) whose features are listed in Table 2.
1 Natural aggregate include the crushed lime aggregate.
Table 3 tabulated the physical properties of Nano clay powder. The SEM image of Nano clay is illustrated in Fig. 1.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Granular styrene-butadiene-styrene (SBS) polymer
sections.text: The polystyrene cluster contained up to 300 styrene molecules while the elastic poly butadiene part of the middle encompassed 1300 butadiene molecules supplied from BASF Company.

sections.heading: 3.2. Samples preparation
sections.text:
In order to achieve modified bitumen, pure bitumen, nanoclay and SBS polymer were mixed at 4 percentage levels relative to virgin binder weight through use of ultrasonic high shear mixer at 170 C for one hour in a pressurized closed vessel.
Prior to preparing the asphalt samples for Rutting test, the optimal bitumen content relevant to each percentage of Nano-polymer composite was found using Marshall Test based on ASTM–D1559 standard [27]. The optimum bitumen content was determined as 5.3% of HMA weight. Table 4 offers the routes for the prepared samples and the experimental tests. The selected additives were of type A-E and each type percentage is listed in Table 5.

sections.heading: 3.3. Experimental tests
sections.text: Marshall Test, wheel-tracking test, static creep test, repeated axial load test (RLA) and the dynamic creep test are the commonly test methods to assess the resistance of asphalt mixtures against permanent deformation [28]. The repetitive axial loading test, Nottingham Asphalt Test (NAT) and wheel track test (WTT) were employed to examine the features of the asphalt mixtures under permanent deformation. Rheological properties of modified bitumen were determined by asphalt binder test as well.

sections.heading: 3.3.1. Rheological tests
sections.text:
Binder stiffness is one of the most importance features which is usually examined by rheological parameters. The optimal additive content was determined by rheological tests such as penetration grade, softening point, ductility and dynamic shear rheometer (DSR) on conventional and modified bitumen containing different
additive levels. Table 6 presents the list of laboratory tests of the present work.

sections.heading: 3.3.2. Marshall strength
sections.text: Marshall Test (ASTM D1559) involved submerging the cylindrical samples (diameter of 101 mm and height of 63.5 mm) in water at 60 C for 30–40 min. The samples then underwent a load at constant pressure rate of 51 mm/min until their failure point through use of curved steel loading plates along their diameter. The deformation at maximum force was considered as the flow (in mm), whereas the maximum force during compression was recorded as Marshall Stability value (in kN) [27].

sections.heading: 3.3.3. Repeated load axial test (RLA)
sections.text:
Nottingham Asphalt Test device was introduced in 1980 to perform under dynamic loading conditions to evaluate the mechanical properties of asphalt mixtures. Poisson’s ratio of 0.35 is generally regarded as indicator of the best asphalt material behavior. This factor is entered in NAT device as an input prior to stiffness modulus test [29] (Figs. 2 and 3).
Repeated load axial test (RLA) was employed to assess the impact of various variables of asphalt mixtures on its resistance to permanent deformation. The mentioned test involves application of an axial load on the samples and continuous measurement of the permanent deformation utilizing two sensors. This test was carried out in compliance with British Standard (BS) DD185 [30] (Fig. 4).

sections.heading: 3.3.4. Wheel tracking test (WTT)
sections.text: This test is aimed to evaluate asphalt mixture accelerated performance in terms of rutting resistance. Conventional WTT involved submerging of hot asphalt mixture in hot water followed by rolling steel wheel across its surface. This test is also applicable under dry conditions. Both steel and solid rubber wheels can be employed. WTT is conducted at controlled temperatures within a cabinet at different tire pressures. Maximum impression (rut depth) can be defined as the highest deformation assessed at any location along the wheel-track. In cases where the rut depths of two laboratories compacted slabs differ by more than 6 mm and the consequent test gave rise to calculation failure, the test will be considered invalid and has to be re-conducted. WTT of this study employed asphalt specimens (30 30 cm2 and height of 5 cm). Wheel tracker was adjusted to shut off upon maximum LVDT displacement of 20 mm.

sections.heading: 4.1. Asphalt binder tests
sections.text:
Rheological tests conducted on unmodified and modified bitumen samples containing various additives content included penetration, softening point, ductility and dynamic shear rheometer (DSR) tests. Table 7 and Fig. 5 illustrate the findings. As observed, incorporation of various percentages of additives showed to have positive impact on the rheological properties of bitumen.

Based on the findings, modified bitumen exhibited lower sensitivity to high temperature changes; moreover it may also possess higher resistance toward plastic deformation (rutting) compared to its unmodified counterparts. The results also suggest that addition of Nano polymer composite materials can improve the softening point of bitumen through reducing its temperature sensitivity. Ductility is reduced by increasing Nano Polymer composite content and improvement of modified bitumen stiffness in comparison to conventional bitumen. Reducing the oily materials in maltene phase, increase viscosity and stiffness and existence of Nano Polymer particles in the slimming part of specimen which have not deformation capability resulted in less ductility.

sections.heading: 4.2. Dynamic shear rheometer (DSR)
sections.text:
DSR temperature sweep test was carried out under controlled strain in which a constant frequency of 10 rad/s was maintained. In order to maintain all the results within the linear viscoelastic range, an adequately low strain force was applied. Phase angle and the complex modulus were automatically measured at temperatures range of 46–82 C. Fig. 6a–d clearly indicate the temperature dependence of complex modulus (G*) along with phase angle of both Nano polymer-modified and conventional bitumen in the mentioned temperatures range. According to the results, the complex modulus of modified asphalt binders increased while a decrease can be observed in its phase angle when compared with
its unmodified counterpart. A declined can be detected in the slopes of modified asphalt master curves (G*) compared to unmodified one (temperature range of 64–82 C). By temperature elevation, the phase angles of unmodified and modified asphalt samples enhanced; the modified bitumen however showed lower sensitivity to temperature variation. Therefore, it can be said that, the modified asphalt binders managed to exhibit enhanced capability in maintaining elastic/viscous ability compared to its unmodified counterparts.

sections.heading: 4.3. Marshall stability and flow test
sections.text:
Marshall Test stability and flow values are listed in Table 8 for each sample containing optimal content of Nano polymer additives (Type D) and different levels of bitumen. These values are the average of three replicates. Clearly, incorporation of Nano clay and SBS polymer resulted in enhancement of Marshall Stability values. It seems that addition of Nano polymer composite enhanced the binders’ stiffness as the result of its unique features like high hardness. Hence, the stability of the Nano polymer-containing mixtures led to higher values compared to control ones.
Maximum stability and unit weight as well as allowed median limits for air voids (VA limits was 4.0–7.0% for wearing course) were among the criteria employed to select the optimal bitumen content. The average asphalt cement (AC) was determined for any of the three mentioned factors, these amount were then verified to comply with requirements of VA, VMA, stability and flow. The optimum bitumen content of the control and modified specimens are shown in Table 8. For determination of HMA basic physical properties, all methods of design mix used density and voids. Theoretical maximum density and bulk density are the two major density measuring methods. Considering the densities including voids in the total mix (VTM), voids in the mineral aggregate (VMA) and voids filled with asphalt (VFA), the following volumetric HMA parameters were obtained.

sections.heading: 4.4. Repeated load axial test (RLA)
sections.text:
Under repeated load condition, HMA will experience a plastic deformation called permanent deformation. The features of permanent deformation in pavement materials can be found by use of a repeated dynamic load test for several times along with measuring the accumulated permanent deformation as a function of cycle number. Besides, the impact of various factors of asphalt mixtures on permanent deformation resistance, as well as creep response of the modified asphalt can be elucidated using RLA test. Figs. 7 and 8 present the final strain of both conventional and Nano polymer modified asphalt mixture under different stress and temperatures conditions.
At a given temperature, final strain of the modified samples was lower than the conventional one. Hence, modified samples will exhibit lower permanent deformation in comparison with the conventional specimens. In comparison with conventional asphalt samples, stronger asphalt binder-aggregates adhesion in modified samples can be mentioned as the major reason for the decline in final strain. Furthermore, as Figs. 7 and 8 suggest, for modified asphalt mixtures, increase in the stress resulted in slower incremental rate for the rutting depth at a specific temperature. It can

sections.heading: 4.5. Wheel track test (WTT)
sections.text:
The validity of the modified and conventional asphalt mixtures was confirmed by WTT which measured the rutting depth at vari-
ous temperatures and tire pressures. The RLA-predicted rutting depth and the one predicted by WTT can be observed in Tables 9 and 10.
Tables 9 and 10 compare the WTT-measured rutting depth with the one predicted by the empirical model for conventional and modified samples. Accordingly, the proposed model and parameter functions can predict the viscoelasto-plastic behavior of the modified and conventional asphalt mixtures.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text:
The aim of the present study was to examine the rutting resistance of Hot Mix Asphalt mixtures containing steel slag aggregates along with investigation of the mechanical and rheological features of asphalt binders modified by Nano clay and polymer SBS. Various analyses were conducted on asphalt binders and mixtures containing different modifier contents. It can be concluded that enhancement of Nano polymer composite percentage in the modified binders will cause a decline and enhancement in the penetration and softening point of the mixtures, respectively; which can indicate the hardness and stiffness rise in these mixtures. In
comparison with unmodified bitumen, modified bitumen exhibited declined sensitivity to high temperatures and probably higher resistance toward rutting (plastic deformation).
Enhanced viscosity and improved adhesion to aggregate particles could be regarded as other advantages of Nano polymer modified bitumen. At lower temperatures, softer (less stiff) binders naturally exhibit more flexibility and less cracking formation. Such binders however act poorly at elevated temperatures. Based on the present study, the rutting performance was highly influenced by binder modification in HMA mixtures. Improved rutting resistance in HMA mixtures showed a significant association with stiffer
binders (higher viscosity), in particular, at higher temperatures. Higher Marshal Stability is the result of Nano particles incorporation in SSAM as compared to control samples. In comparison with conventional asphalt mixtures, modified samples possessed higher rates of final strain upon stress enhancement at any temperature. In the other words, modified samples showed lower sensitivity to stress than the conventional ones which led to higher rutting resistance of modified samples. Horizontal tensile stress-induced tensile and vertical cracks formation and propagation was avoided in the SSAM which contained Nano clay and polymer SBS. The proposed creep compliance model was illustrated as a 3-D graph; it suggests that in spite of strong correlation between temperature and strain in all samples, the creep behavior improved in samples containing Nano and polymer additives even at high levels of stress and temperature. WTT-measured rutting depth values versus empirically predicted values are presented for conventional and modified asphalt mixtures; both measured and predicted plots showed a straight line. Therefore, the proposed model and parameter functions can predict the viscoelasto-plastic behavior of the conventional and modified samples at different stress and temperature levels.

referenceMentions.context: As an organic mixture with wide range of applications in road pavement industry, asphalt has imposed itself as an ideal mixture for this purpose owing to its good viscoelastic features [1].
Road pavements must exhibit acceptable resistance against fatigue cracking, rutting, creep and slippage [2].
Asphalt mixture has to demonstrate resistance against weather influences, permanent deformation and cracking resulted by loading and environmental factors [3].
Other factors like overloading, long steep slopes, low-speed trucks, substance properties, and climate conditions can also influence rutting in asphalt pavement [2].

With increasing loads and number of axles on the roads, particularly those of overweight (OW) and superheavy loads (SHL), highway agencies need to adopt policies for accommodating this increase without jeopardizing pavement performance [4,5].

Nanotechnology deals with particles with at least one characteristics dimension in the length scale of 1–100 nm [9].
In this length scale, asphalt binder particles have different physical and chemical properties mainly due to their high surface area and quantum effects [10].
The history of nanotechnology dates back to exploration of gold colloidal solution by Michael Faraday in 1857 [11].
However, the fundamentals of this science became well established in the past half a century [12].

In general, nanomaterials can improve the performance of asphalt mixtures by potentially improving one or some of asphalt mixture properties including adhesion between asphalt binder and aggregates, asphalt binder cohesion, cracking resistance, moisture resistance, wearing course performance, and layer interface bond [13].

metadata.abstractText: Nanoparticles have exhibited a promising potential in enhancing the bituminous materials’ performance. As a cost-effective material, hot mix asphalt (HMA) has been employed in pavement structure for a long time. Their viscoelasticity however results in various modes of failure under different temperature profiles and loading stress. Rutting of asphalt pavements is considered as the most prominent distress factor under almost all climate conditions. Moreover, steel slag has been employed for improvement of asphalt mixture properties as it exhibits excellent physical features. In this content the aim of the present research is to analyze improving effects of nano clay and styrene-butadiene-styrene (SBS) on the rutting resistance of modified steel slag asphalt mixture (SSAM). Various tests were employed to investigate the asphalt binder properties and the rheological characteristics of modified bitumen among which penetration grade, softening point, ductility and dynamic shear rheometer (DSR) can be mentioned. Marshal Test was applied to examine the optimum bitumen content in conventional and modified asphalt mixture. The rutting resistance against was then evaluated through two tests: repeated load axial (RLA) test and wheel track test. The results indicated respective improvement of toughness and viscosity by an average of 25% and 101% upon addition of nano-polymer which enhanced the bitumen rheological characteristics while reducing the penetration grade. The asphalt rutting resistance and rutting depth exhibited some improvements as well. 2019 Published by Elsevier Ltd.
